head.title: A Mouse Made for Heavy Drinking

hedline.hl1: A Mouse Made for Heavy Drinking

abstract.p: Scientists at University of Washington create a mouse that drinks much more alcohol than a normal mouse and that may therefore be useful in study of alcoholism; cartoon (S)

block.p: First it was mice that could eat to their hearts' content without getting fat. Now it's mice that can hold their alcohol better and recover from it faster.

First, scientists at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey reported that they had created a genetically modified mouse that could eat with abandon. The long-term objective is better understanding of human obesity.
First it was mice that could eat to their hearts' content without getting fat. Now it's mice that can hold their alcohol better and recover from it faster.

First, scientists at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey reported that they had created a genetically modified mouse that could eat with abandon. The long-term objective is better understanding of human obesity.
Now, scientists at the University of Washington report creating a mouse that drinks much more alcohol than it would ordinarily. The goal here is more insight into alcoholism.
The researchers say they have bred mice missing a gene that bears instructions for making an important brain protein. The mice, they say, drink twice as much alcohol as do mice with the protein.

And, given injections of alcohol raising blood-alcohol level to almost three times the driving limit, the mice recovered in about 65 minutes. (Ordinary mice needed about 90.) The findings were reported in a recent issue of The Journal of Neuroscience.
